awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for the Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG) to build and sustain essential cyberinfrastructure and computational capacity for geodynamics and seismology. Over the past decade, CIG has developed and disseminated widely-used, open-source codes for research and education in computational seismology, mantle convection, magma dynamics, short- and long-term lithospheric and crustal deformation, and geodynamo modeling. CIG has changed the culture in computational geophysics research by improving scientific software development practices and has influenced the education of hundreds of geodynamicists. CIG?s approach towards writing and disseminating scientific software has become indispensable to its community and has established and sustained deep ties to computational sciences.

Scientific computation is integral to solid Earth geosciences, allowing us to understand and quantify the processes that shape Earth. Computational models link observations and quantitative models describing the Earth?s interior and evolution. This project will continue the development and dissemination of high quality scientific software to enable cutting edge geodynamics modeling, and to prepare a diverse workforce to address fundamental science questions. While CIG?s primary mission is development of high-quality open-source software, a growing role is the education and development of geoscientists who are prepared to effectively use and advance computation in research and teaching. Workshops, hackathons, meeting special sessions, and tutorials foster emerging computational geoscientists who represent the long-term legacy of the project.

por.por_cntn:
The Computational Infrastructure for Geodynamics (CIG) provides the software cyberinfrastructure that facilitates transformative research in geodynamics by a broad community of scientists ranging from model developers to end users. The computational infrastructure provided by CIG is driven by community needs and defined by community participation, and includes: (a) reusable, well documented, open-source geodynamics software and tools; (b) support for a virtual community that facilitates intellectual exchange and partnerships between computational scientists and Earth scientists; and (c) specialized training, workshops, and outreach for the Earth science community. 

CIG supports scientific communities in modeling mantle convection, short- and long-term lithospheric and crustal deformation, seismic wave propagation and seismic cycles, solar and planetary dynamos, and multiphysics processes. Community software draws on actively developed numerical libraries used across fields in science and engineering. Its established and domain leading best practices for software have created and enabled robust, well-documented, and well-tested codes. Through engagement with the broader computational and software communities', CIG's best practices for research software and software engineering are continually improved, implemented, and disseminated to the community. CIG advocates for and implements as part of its best practices guidance for software citation to support the reproducibility of research results and to provide appropriate credit for scientific software developers.

This approach to developing software as community projects has brought state-of-the art computational methods to more researchers enabling CIG's open-source scientific source software to be widely used for research and education. CIG software is routinely used by hundreds of scientists for transformative research on the fastest computing systems worldwide. Training through workshops and pioneering hackathons targeting early early-career scientists has built active user and user-developer code communities. Codes initially established with few developers now have tens and upward of a hundred contributors. CIG established and/or grew four flagship code communities ASPECT, PyLith, Rayleigh, and SPECFEM creating a stable base of developers and users. CIG has started the development of a code community for seismic cycles and seeded projects to further geoscientific education and model building. Research driven development by CIG members and contributors worldwide has continuously expanded these codes to support the next generation of computer systems and enable the next generation of cutting edge geoscientific research. The CIG community has published over 800 peer-reviewed scientific publications and student theses using these codes.

CIG leveraged its experience in hosting virtual outreach events to engage a broader and international community (Figure 1). Webinar and in-person and virtual workshop and hackathon participants represented six (6) continents and helped to prepare a more diverse STEM workforce who are qualified to use the developed computational and geosciences skills to an even broader scope of societal challenges. CIG scientists work in careers in academia, industry and government.

Intellectual Merit

CIG software is used in a wide breadth of research in the geosciences to understand the development of structures in subduction and rifting zones, origin and dynamics of mantle plumes, understanding how carbon and other critical elements move in the Earth, determining the origin and dynamics of the Earth's magnetic dynamo; Earth's response to glacial unloading, and crustal deformation throughout the seismic cycle, earthquake rupture characteristics, and strong ground motions. Partnerships with the computational mathematics community through the deal.II and PETSc projects have advanced the development of these cross-disciplinary libraries and improved the performance and accuracy of computational methods in the geosciences. CIG's single-code hackathons have emerged as a proven, efficient, and emulated model to foster code communities and quickly add important new features to research software and disseminate best practices for software engineering.

Broader Impact

The CIG community engages and seeks to develop a diverse STEM workforce through leadership, education, and outreach. CIG software and tutorials are freely available under OSI approved licenses through hosted software projects and public platforms and have been accessed worldwide (Figure 2). They have improved computational science, computational model development, and the use of high-performance computing for the geosciences.

CIG's research community in academia, government and other agencies tackles a wide range of problems that have societal impact related to Earth's response to climate change, the impact of the energy transition on the environment, and natural hazards. Research enabled by CIG software contributes to geohazard models, public safety, and K-12 and public education and outreach through activities by local CIG member institutions and online.
